<style>
blockquote blockquote p { font-size: 10pt; }
</style>

In this tutorial we're going to build on the blog app from the [previous tutorial](https://www.learnbyhacking.org/posts/532694fa13c6142d4f000013) by adding some new features:

* Ability to edit existing post.
* Adding authors to posts.
* Allowing authors to not make a post public until it's ready.

I assume that you've gone through the getting stated tutorial and have a working [memblog](https://github.com/scslab/lio/tree/master/lio-simple/examples/memblog).  I also assume some familiarity with LIO. If you haven't come across LIO before parts of this tutorial will not make sense. At the end I included some links where you can learn more about LIO.

## Private posts

The first thing we're going to do is modify modify the `Post` data type (of `Memblog/Common.hs`) to encode whether or not the post should be publicly readable, i.e., whether or not it has been _published_:

```haskell
-- | Data-type representing a blog post
data Post = Post { postId          :: PostId
                 , postTitle       :: String
                 , postBody        :: String 
                 , postIsPublished :: Bool
                 } deriving (Show, Read)
```

Since values of this type have this additional field, let's modify the dummy posts `post0` and `post1` to set their fields to `True` and `False`, respectively:

```haskell
post0 :: Post
post0 = Post {
  ...
  , postIsPublished = True
  }

post1 :: Post
post1 = Post {
  ...
  , postIsPublished = False
  }
```

Let's also modify our view for creating new posts (`liofs/views/new.html`) to include a checkbox corresponding to this field:


```html
<form action="/" method="POST">
  <div>
    <label for="title">Title</label>
    <input type="text" name="title" id="title"/>
  </div>
  <div>
    <label for="body">Body</label>
    <textarea name="body" id="body"></textarea>
  </div>
  <div>
    <input type="checkbox" name="publish" id="publish"/>
    <label for="publish">Publish?</label>
  </div>
  <input type="submit" value="Create"/>
</form>
```

Finally, let's modify the corresponding controller (in `Application.hs`) to parse this additional parameter, which is present only when the checkbox is selected:

```haskell
...
import Data.Maybe
...

    post "/" $ do
      (params, _) <- parseForm
      let mpost :: Maybe Post
          mpost = do
            pTitle <- lookup "title" params
            pBody  <- lookup "body" params
            let pub = isJust $ lookup "publish" params
            if S8.null pTitle || S8.null pBody
              then fail "Invalid form"
              else return $ Post { postId          = undefined
                                 , postTitle       = S8.unpack pTitle
                                 , postBody        = S8.unpack pBody 
                                 , postIsPublished = pub
                                 }
```

Let's finally modify the view that displays a post (`liofs/views/show.html`) to give the user the option to modify unpublished posts:

```html
<h2>$postTitle$</h2>
<p>
  $postBody$
</p>
<hr />
$if(postIsPublished)$
  This post has been published.
$else$
  <a href="/$postId$/edit">Edit post.</a>
$endif$
```

If you point your browser to the [first post ](http://localhost:3000/0) you should see:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="618" height="354">

However, if you point it to the [second post](http://localhost:3000/1), you'll notice the "Edit post" link:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="618" height="354">

That's it for this feature! It's not exactly useful yet, since we ideally want to avoid listing, in the index page, unpublished posts, but for now let's leave it as is. Later we'll modify the app to only show public posts or posts that the _current user_ is working on (but we haven't gotten to users just yet).

## Edit posts

Above, we created an "Edit post" link, but have not yet defined a view or controller for editing posts.  So, let's add a new view that presents a form similar to that of "new.html", but additionally populates some of the information. Specifically, create a new file `liofs/views/edit.html` with the following:

```html
<form action="/$postId$" method="POST">
  <div>
    <label for="title">Title</label>
    <input type="text" name="title" id="title" value="$postTitle$"/>
  </div>
  <div>
    <label for="body">Body</label>
    <textarea name="body" id="body">$postBody$</textarea>
  </div>
  <div>
    <input type="checkbox" name="publish" 
           id="publish" $if(postIsPublished)$ checked="true" $endif$/>
    <label for="publish">Publish?</label>
  </div>
  <input type="submit" value="Update"/>
</form>
```
Note that in addition to populating the corresponding fields, the form action now points to "/$postId$" as opposed to simply "/". This is used to distinguish between the creation of a new post and updating an existing one (really, we may also want to use the HTTP PUT method instead of POST). Before we define the route that responds to this submitted form, let's first handle the edit request by adding the following controller to our `Application.hs`:

```haskell
    get "/:pId/edit" $ do
      pId     <- queryParam' "pId"
      curPost <- getPostById pId
      render "edit.html" curPost
```

Straight forward! It's like combining the `show` and `new` controllers. Now when you click on the second post's [edit link](http://localhost:3000/1/edit) you should the populated form:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="618" height="354">

Let's complete the feature by handling the POST request from the edit form.  Since the code form information is identical to that of creating a new post, let's first factor out the form parsing functionality into a new function:

```haskell
formToPost :: Maybe PostId -> DCController AppSettings Post
formToPost mpId = do
  (params, _) <- parseForm
  let mpost :: Maybe Post
      mpost = do
        pTitle <- lookup "title" params
        pBody  <- lookup "body" params
        let pub = isJust $ lookup "publish" params
        if S8.null pTitle || S8.null pBody
          then fail "Invalid form"
          else return $ Post { postId          = pId
                             , postTitle       = S8.unpack pTitle
                             , postBody        = S8.unpack pBody 
                             , postIsPublished = pub }
  case mpost of
    Nothing -> redirectBack
    Just p  -> return p
  where pId = fromMaybe undefined mpId
```

This function first parses the HTTP request to extract the "title", "body", and "published" fields. If the first two are missing or null then `mpost` value is `Nothing` and `formToPost` returns a response corresponding to a redirect to the referrer (`redirectBack`). Recall that if a response is returned then the`DCController` monad does not execute the remaining actions. Hence, `formToPost` performing redirect is akin to a failure -- the redirect response percolates and is returned by the top-most controller.

Note that if the fields are present and not null (the "publsh" field is present only when the checkbox is selected) then `formToPost` returns the `Post` value with these corresponding fields set. As before, the post id is set to `undefined` if this is a new post and we expect the database interface to "adjust" this field.

The controller for creating a new post now becomes very simple:

```haskell
    post "/" $ do
      curPost <- formToPost Nothing
      pId     <- insertPost curPost
      respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
```

And, our new controller for updating a post is also not any more complex:

```haskell
    post "/:pId" $ do
      pId     <- queryParam' "pId"
      curPost <- formToPost (Just pId)
      updatePost curPost
      respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
```

But, what is this `updatePost` function?

Well, we haven't yet defined it (you may want to define it as `undefined` if you want to compiler your code); our database interface only has `insertPost`. So, let's pull up `Memblog/Common.hs` and add this new function:

```haskell
updatePost :: Post -> DCController AppSettings ()
updatePost post = do
  settings  <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "updatePost" $ do
    posts <- takeLMVar $ db settings
    putLMVar (db settings) $ map f posts
  where f p = if postId p == postId post then post else p
```

This function is pretty straight forward. First, it gets the controller state and extracts the in-memory database (with `db`).  Then, it extracts the posts and takes a lock on the database (with `takeLMVar`).  With `map` we update the `posts` list by simply replacing the element that has the same id as the post supplied to `updatePost`, leaving all other elements intact.  Finally, we use this updated list as the database and release the lock (with `putLMVar`).

Now when if we click on the checkbox in the edit form of our second post (modify the title) and click "Update", we'll be redirected to the post:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="618" height="354">

Note that now the "Edit post" link is no longer present: we updated the post!


## Adding authors

Okay, so up to this point we have the ability to edit posts and declare them as published (or leave them as drafts). The latter feature is not really in full use just yet though: we want to hide the drafts until the _author_ is ready to publish the post. But, in order to do this we need a notion of authors and users.


### Users

First, let's modify `Common.hs` to add a type for users:

```haskell
-- | UserName's are just Strings
type UserName = String
```

Now let's use `lio-simple`'s basic authentication middleware by modifying the `main` function in `Main.hs`:

```haskell
...
import LIO.Web.Simple
import LIO.Web.Simple.Auth
...

main :: IO ()
main = do
    -- Run app
    env <- getEnvironment
    let port = maybe 3000 read $ lookup "PORT" env
    evalDC $ app $ run port logStdout . authMiddleware

authMiddleware :: SimpleMiddleware DC
authMiddleware = basicAuth "memblog-2" (\_ _ -> return True)
```

The middleware uses [HTTP Basic Authentication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_access_authentication) to authenticate the user (when we request it to do so).  Since this is just a toy app any username/password combination is accepted (hence the authentication function is a lambda term that returns `True`).  Let's add a function in `Application.hs` that executes a controller with a username and otherwise requests this middleware to authenticate the user:

```haskell
...
import LIO.Web.Simple.Auth
...

withUser :: (UserName -> DCController AppSettings ()) 
         -> DCController AppSettings ()
withUser act = withUserOrLogin $ \user -> act (S8.unpack user)
```

Now, let's add a new route in `Application.hs` that actually requests the user to login if they haven't:


```haskell
    get "/login" $ withUser $ \_ -> respond . redirectTo $ "/"
```

Make sure to place this controller before the `get "/:pId"` controller, otherwise it will never be dispatched.

Now, point your browser to <http://localhost:3000/login>; you should see:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

But, maybe we want to give the user some feedback that they're logged in. So,let's modify this controller to render a page that welcomes the user:

```haskell
    get "/login" $ withUser $ \user ->
      render "login.html" $ object ["user" .= user]
```

You must also add the new template that is rendered by this controller in `liofs/views/login.html`:

```html
Welcome, $user$!
```

Now, when you point your browser to <http://localhost:3000/login> and type in a username, you should see:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

### Authors

Now that we have an (albeit poor) authentication system, we can modify our data model to include authors:

```haskell
-- | Data-type representing a blog post
data Post = Post { postId          :: PostId
                 , postTitle       :: String
                 , postBody        :: String 
                 , postIsPublished :: Bool
                 , postAuthor      :: UserName
                 } deriving (Show, Read)
```

As with the `postIsPublished` we must modify the dummy posts:

```haskell
post0 :: Post
post0 = Post {
  ...
  , postAuthor = "cicero"
  }

post1 :: Post
post1 = Post {
  ...
  , postAuthor = "cicero"
  }
```

Then, we need to modify `Application.hs` to account for the authors when creating and updating posts.

To this end, we first update our `formToPost` function to take an additional argument for the current user:

```haskell
formToPost :: UserName -> Maybe PostId -> DCController AppSettings Post
formToPost user mpId = do
  (params, _) <- parseForm
  let mpost :: Maybe Post
      mpost = do
        pTitle <- lookup "title" params
        pBody  <- lookup "body" params
        let pub = isJust $ lookup "publish" params
        if S8.null pTitle || S8.null pBody
          then fail "Invalid form"
          else return $ Post { postId          = pId
                             , postTitle       = S8.unpack pTitle
                             , postBody        = S8.unpack pBody 
                             , postIsPublished = pub
                             , postAuthor      = user }
  case mpost of
    Nothing -> redirectBack'
    Just p  -> return p
  where pId = fromMaybe undefined mpId
        redirectBack' =  do 
          redirectBack 
          return $ error "future version of simple won't need this type fix"
```

And update the two routes to force the login:

```haskell
    post "/" $ withUser $ \user -> do
      curPost <- formToPost user Nothing
      pId     <- insertPost curPost
      respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
    post "/:pId" $ withUser $ \user -> do
      pId     <- queryParam' "pId"
      curPost <- formToPost user (Just pId)
      updatePost curPost
      respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
```

What does this mean? Well, now you can only create a new post or update an existing post if you are logged in!

But, if you navigate your browser to <http://localhost:3000/new> (or corresponding edit page) without logging-in you will still get the HTML form. Why is that? Well we're only forcing you to be logged in at the time of a modification (with POST), so you will only get the prompt at the time you click the "Create" (or "Update") buttons. If you want to make the app a bit more friendly, modify the "new" and "edit" routes to force a login:

```haskell
    get "/new" $ withUser $ \user -> do
...
    get "/:pId/edit" $ withUser $ \user -> do
...
```

Before we get into the details of who is allow to modify what, let's modify the index and show pages to add the post author as additional information.

Modify `liofs/views/index.html` to:

```html
$if(null(posts))$
  No posts.
$else$
  <ul>
  $for(post in posts)$
    <li><a href="/$post.postId$">$post.postTitle$</a> by $post.postAuthor$</li>
  $endfor$
  </ul>
$endif$
```

Modify `liofs/views/show.html` to:

```html
<h2>$postTitle$</h2>
<h3>$postAuthor$</h3>
<p>
  $postBody$
</p>
<hr />
$if(postIsPublished)$
  This post has been published.
$else$
  <a href="/$postId$/edit">Edit post.</a>
$endif$
```

Your main page should now look something like:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="618" height="354">

## Security policy

Alright, we now have a blog app wherein there is an author associated with a post. The app is a bit of mess though: one user can modify the blog post of another, unpublished blogs are publicly accessible, etc. So, let's fix this.

First, let's concretely specify the security policies we want:

1. Only the author of the post is allowed to read the post if it has not been published; published posts are publicly readable.

2. Only the author of the post is allowed to modify the post content,

Notice that both of these policies are _on_ and _depend on_ data! They don't say anything about what a particular piece of code is allowed or not allowed to do: when thinking about policy we care about the data, not about code.  This is precisely one of the principles behind [Hails](http://www.scs.stanford.edu/~deian/pubs/giffin:2012:hails.pdf), our secure framework built atop LIO.

Since the monad underlying our controllers is `DC`, i.e., `LIO` with `DCLabel`s, we can use the confinement and access control features of LIO to accomplish our goal of enforcing policy by associating it with data.  (In a separate post I will consider a more traditional approach to enforcing these policies.)

**Terminology** I will use the name "LIO" interchangeably with "LIO + DCLabels", and "label" with "DCLabel".  However, if you prefer using other label types, like Jif's [DLM](http://www.cs.cornell.edu/andru/papers/iflow-tosem.ps.gz), you can do so!

In LIO, policies are specified in the form of _labels_. A label is value of the form `secrecy %% integrity` where `secrecy` and `integrity` are logical formulas in [conjunctive-normal-form]().  For the purpose of this tutorial you can think of the secrecy component as indicating who is allowed to read labeled as such, and the integrity specifying who created and is allowed to modify the data. For instance, the label `"alice" \/ "bob" %% "bob"` specifies:

* **secrecy:** that a piece of data labeled as such is sensitive to either "alice" or "bob" and, thus, should only be readable by somebody that can _speak for_ "alice" or "bob" (really, "alice" or "bob").

* **integrity:** that a piece of data labeled as such was created and can be modified by "bob"

### Secrecy policy: drafts are only readable by authors

Checkout the [DCLabels paper](http://www.scs.stanford.edu/~deian/pubs/stefan:2011:dclabels.pdf) if you're interested in learning more labels.  For now, let's define a function (in `Memblog/Common.hs`) that is used to generate a policy from a post:

```haskell
postPolicy :: Post -> DCLabel
postPolicy post = let author = postAuthor post
                  in  if postIsPublished post
                        then True   %% True
                        else author %% True
```

The policy this function generates only expresses our first high-level security concern: only the author of the post is allowed to read the post if it has not been published; published posts are publicly readable.  Concretely, `postPolicy` generates `author %% True` if the post is still a draft (and thus should only readable by the author) and `True %% True` if the post is public. Here, `True` corresponds to the least restricting component (in the case of secrecy it means public, in the case of integrity it means untrusted).

Of course, just defining this policy function doesn't actually do anything: we need to associate such generated labels with posts.

To this end, let's modify the type of our database to associate labels with posts. While we're at it, let's use a better data structure, namely a map (from post id's to labeled posts):

```haskell
...
import Data.Map (Map)
import qualified Data.Map as Map
import Data.Foldable
import Data.Traversable
...

data AppSettings = AppSettings { 
  db :: LMVar DCLabel (Map PostId (Labeled DCLabel Post))
}
```

The `Data.Map` module is part of the containers package `containers`, so you must also add it to the of dependencies in `memblog.cabal` before running `cabal run`.  (We'll need to fix up a few other places after this change; this will be taken care of shortly.)

Now, each post in the database is wrapped as a `Labeled` value, which keeps track of both the post and label used to protect the post. LIO ensures that code can only inspect the contents (post) of a labeled value if it can guarantee that the code cannot thereafter leak the data (post).  (Note that since the post id is used in as the key to the map, this means that post ids are always public!) Labeled values are created and destroyed with `label` and `unlabel`, respectively. The types for these function (with DCLabels)  are given below:

```haskell
label   :: DCLabel -> a -> DC (Labeled DCLabel a)
unlabel :: DLabeled DCLabel a -> DC a
```

One thing the `LIO` monad does (when compared with `IO`) is keep track of a _current label_, which is conceptually the label on _everything_ in scope. (You can get the current label with `getLabel`.) Hence, when you `label` a value with a label, you are effectively saying that the value will be protected by this new label (as opposed to the current label). Thus when `unlabel`ing a labeled value you will now be able to inspect the boxed value, but the current label has been "raised" (and thus restricts where you can write and thus leak this data).

With this in mind, let's define a helper function for actually associating labels with posts:

```haskell
labelPost :: Post -> DC (Labeled DCLabel Post)
labelPost post = withContext "labelPost" $ label (postPolicy post) post
```

This function simply applies the policy function to create a label and then associates this label with a post, returning a labeled value. It's such labeled posts that we want to place in the database.

In fact, since the above modification to `AppSettings` broke our app, we now have a number of places that we need to go and adjust the code to handle labeled posts.

First, let's modify our `newAppSettings` that creates a value of this type:

```haskell
newAppSettings :: DC AppSettings
newAppSettings = do
  lpost0 <- labelPost post0
  lpost1 <- labelPost post1
  mv <- newLMVar dcPublic $ Map.fromList [(postId post0, lpost0), (postId post1, lpost1)]
  return $ AppSettings { db = mv }
```

In the first two lines we label the dummy posts with `labelPost` and then write the maps containing these two posts to the `LMVar`.

> > **Note:** In a real application the database interface would be abstracted (as it is to code in `Application.hs`) and we would instead have to use `insertPost`.

Let's now modify `getAllPosts` to handle labeled posts:

```haskell
...
import Control.Monad (liftM)
...

getAllPosts :: DCController AppSettings [Post]
getAllPosts = do
  settings <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "getAllPosts" $ do
    lposts <- readLMVar $ db settings
    foldlM f [] lposts
   where f posts lpost = do post <- unlabel lpost
                            return $ post : posts
```

Here, we use `foldM` to iterate over the labeled posts, unlabeling each one.

If you want to make sure that what we've done to the app works so far, declare `insertPost` and `updatePost` as `undefined`:

```haskell
insertPost = undefined
updatePost = undefined
```

Now, when go to <http://localhost:3000>, you will see:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

But, wait -- we can still see Cicero's posts! Wasn't the whole point of the labeling precisely to avoid this?  What's going on?

Well LIO is an information flow control system, so by default it allows code to read arbitrarily sensitive data at the cost of raising the current label. In fact, if you modify the "/" controller to:

```haskell
    get "/" $ do
      posts <- getAllPosts
      label <- liftLIO $ getLabel
      render "index.html" $ object ["posts" .= posts, "label" .= show label ]
```

and add:

```html
Current label = $label$
```

to the end of `liofs/views/index.html`.  Now, when you visit <http://localhost:3000> you will also see the current label:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

Note that that current label is not the public label!  The label indicates that the computation has read data sensitive to user "cicero".  Since we made the request without logging in, our ability to see Cicero's posts is a leak; we should not be sending arbitrarily-sensitive data to the browser.  Instead, we should make sure that the computation only sends data that the user is allowed to see.

We can do this by making sure that the final current label can flow to the implicit label of the browser (`user %% True`) and only then send the request. But this means that the app will still be able to read data that is more sensitive than what it can ultimately send to the user. So, we will instead enforce an even stronger property: the app cannot access any data that the end user is not allowed to access.  That is, it cannot read data that cannot ultimately be sent to the browser!

LIO's _current clearance_ serves precisely this role.  The clearance restricts the kinds of data the current computation can access.  For example, to restrict reads, clearance serves as an upper bound on the current label; hence, when we try to raise the current label LIO first checks to make sure that this new label will not be above the current clearance.

With this in mind, let's set the clearance to the public label if no user is logged in, restricting the app to reading public data; and, otherwise set it to `user %% True`, restricting it to reading data at most as sensitive as sensitive the logged in `user`.  Specifically, let's open the `Main.hs` and runner function to add a middleware that sets the clearance appropriately:

```haskell
...
import LIO
...

main :: IO ()
main = do
    -- Run app
    env <- getEnvironment
    let port = maybe 3000 read $ lookup "PORT" env
    evalDC $ app $ run port logStdout . authMiddleware
                                      . setClearanceMiddleware

...

setClearanceMiddleware :: SimpleMiddleware DC
setClearanceMiddleware app req = do
  case lookup "X-User" $ requestHeaders req of
    Just user -> setClearance $ principalBS user %% cTrue
    _         -> setClearance dcPublic
  app req
```

This middleware is executed after the authentication middleware (`authMiddleware`); it simply sets the clearance then executes our `app`, as defined in `Application.hs`, with this clearance.

Now, when you visit <http://localhost:3000> you will get an error message:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="616" height="445">

If you look at the app log the reason for the failure is:

```haskell
LabelError { lerrContext = ["getAllPosts","unlabel"]
           , lerrFailure = "taint"
           , lerrCurLabel = True %% True
           , lerrCurClearance = True %% True
           , lerrPrivs  = []
           , lerrLabels = ["cicero" %% True] }
```

This is telling us that our `getAllPosts` function failed when trying to `unlabel` a post whose label was `"cicero" %% True`.  The particular function that failed was `taint` and at the point of failure the current label and clearance were both the public label `True %% True`. The reason for failure is that we tried to raise the current label with `taint` above the current clearance to `"cicero" %% True`!

Okay, so this stops the app from reading data that the end user is not allowed to see: in this case we were not logged in, so the computation is only allowed to read public, published posts.  Unfortunately, the `getAllPosts` function fails if _any_ post in the database is above the current clearance, so even though the app should be allowed to read the first dummy post (`post0`) that has been published.

So, let's modify `getAllPosts` to only return posts that the current computation is allowed to access:

```haskell
getAllPosts :: DCController AppSettings [Post]
getAllPosts = do
  settings <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "getAllPosts" $ do
    lposts <- readLMVar $ db settings
    foldlM f [] lposts
   where f posts lpost = do handle (handler posts) $ do
                              post <- unlabel lpost
                              return $ post : posts
         handler :: [Post] -> LabelError DCLabel -> DC [Post]
         handler ps _ = return ps
```

Here the function used to iterate over the label posts will try to `unlabel` the labeled post `lpost`; if no exception is raised, the unlabeled post is added to the list, otherwise the list is left intact.  With this change, when you visit <http://localhost:3000> you will not only see Cicero's public post:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

Great! Now, we have an app that will only show posts that the end-user is allowed to see. Let's now define our insert and update functions that we left as `undefined`.

First, let's modify `insertPost`:

```haskell
insertPost :: Post -> DCController AppSettings PostId
insertPost post = do
  settings  <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "insertPost" $ do
    lposts <- takeLMVar $ db settings
    let pId = show $ Map.size lposts
    lpost <- labelPost post { postId = pId }
              `onException` putLMVar (db settings) lposts
    putLMVar (db settings) $ Map.insert pId lpost lposts 
    return pId
```

Now, instead of adding the new post to the existing map of (labeled) posts we must first apply the policy to the post with `labelPost`.  Since we are now using clearance, `labelPost` may fail: in addition to restricting the reading of objects labeled below the clearance, LIO prevents code from writing or creating labeled objects above the clearance. (In other words LIO prevents code from any kind of access above the clearance.) For example, if the request handler is running on behalf of "mr-t", then calling `insertPost` with a `Post { ...  postAuthor = "deian" ... }` will result in an exception being thrown.  Hence, we must be careful to restore the database lock if `labelpost` fails: the `onException` part catches any exceptions, executes the `putLMVar` action to restore the lock, and rethrows the exception.

While we have `Memblog/Common.hs` open let's also update `updatePost`:

```haskell
updatePost :: Post -> DCController AppSettings ()
updatePost post = do
  settings  <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "updatePost" $ do
    lpost  <- labelPost post
    lposts <- takeLMVar $ db settings
    putLMVar (db settings) $ Map.adjust (const lpost) (postId post) lposts
```

The behavior here is as you would expect; `updatePost` simply gets the map of labeled posts (with `takeLMVar`), then adjusts the map by modifying the element whose id corresponds to this post's id.

Okay, now we have everything in place. Let's let's log in as "deian" and create a new draft post.  If we point the browser to <http://localhost:3000/>, we'll see the draft:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

However, if you open a separate browser and don't log in (or log in as a different user) you should you should, again, not see it.  Only when we publish the article will it be shown:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

This completes our first security policy story. It's a bit lengthy, but once you complete this tutorial you should be able to easily reuse our middleware and "database" interface to implement apps with more complex policies and data structures.

### Integrity policy: posts can only be modified by their authors

The app thus far only implements the first policy. Any user can modify posts that have been made public by explicitly navigating to the post's `/edit` page. Moreover, one user can modify the post of any other user by simplify modifying the HTML form of an edit page to have it POST to that particular id.

The second point is a little tricky, so let's consider an example.  Suppose that user "bob" created a post whose id is, say, 2. As user "deian" I create a new dummy post whose id is, say, 3 and point my browser to <http://localhost:3000/3/edit> and modify the HTML form action to be `/2`. Filling in the form and clicking the "Update" button will overwrite "bob"'s post. Why?  Our database is implemented as a pure data-structure, so an update is not actually a mutation: we effectively create a new map every time we modify the database (and are thus avoiding reasoning about modifying individual "database cells").

We can make the database a bit more realistic and allow for explicit mutation, e.g., by modifying `AppSettings` for the second and last time, to:

```haskell
...
import LIO.LIORef
...

data AppSettings = AppSettings { 
  db :: LMVar DCLabel (Map PostId (LIORef DCLabel (Labeled DCLabel Post)))
}
```

In turn, we would have to modify the policy to set the integrity component to the post author for both the labeled value and reference (though for the reference, the secrecy component should be `True`). This is exactly what we want because it not only protects who can modify a post, but the reference label serves as the label _on the label_ of the labeled post. This latter point is important since it specifies who is allowed to modify the label on the post: only the post author can modify the label -- the policy -- on a post (e.g., to make a post public or private).  While this is a nice, clean and general approach we're reaching the point of exhaustion when it comes to the number of concepts you need to understand.  In a later post I will show you how to modify the app to precisely do this.  In this post let's instead take a simpler, less general approach, but still somewhat principled approach.

Since we're using labeled values instead of references when we perform an update we need to make sure that the current computation can actually modify the contents of the database cell, i.e., labeled post. This ensures that the label of the labeled post is protected.  So, to do this, let's modify `updatePost` to:

```haskell
updatePost :: Post -> DCController AppSettings ()
updatePost post = do
  settings  <- controllerState
  liftLIO . withContext "updatePost" $ do
    lpost  <- labelPost post
    lposts <- takeLMVar $ db settings
    guardUpdate (postId post) lposts
      `onException` putLMVar (db settings) lposts
    putLMVar (db settings) $ Map.adjust (const lpost) (postId post) lposts
  where guardUpdate pId lposts = do
          case Map.lookup pId lposts of
            Nothing    -> fail "updatePost: post does not exist"
            Just lpost -> guardAlloc (labelOf lpost)
```

The main change is the new `guardUpdate` (and corresponding exception handler that releases the database lock). This function checks if the post id is in the map, if it's not it throws an exception.  Otherwise, it checks to see if we can (conceptually) write to the labeled cell/value, i.e., it checks (with the allocation-guard `guardAlloc`) if the label of the post is between the current label and current clearance.

With this change in place, let's now modify the function (in `Memblog/Common.hs`) that generates our policy:

```haskell
postPolicy :: Post -> DCLabel
postPolicy post = let author = postAuthor post
                  in  if postIsPublished post
                        then True   %% author
                        else author %% author
```

The modified policy function now contains the `author` in the integrity component (instead of `True`) stating that only the author is allowed to modify a post (whether it's a draft or already published).  But if you run the program now it will immediately crash with an error:

```haskell
 LabelError { lerrContext      = ["labelPost","label"]
            , lerrFailure      = "guardAllocP"
            , lerrCurLabel     = True %% True
            , lerrCurClearance = False %% True
            , lerrPrivs        = []
            , lerrLabels       = [True %% "cicero"] }
```

This is because our `newAppSettings` function is trying to create an object whose label `True %% "cicero"` is below the current clearance, i.e., of higher integrity. As we will see in a short bit, the proper way to address this issue is to use privileges when labeling the posts.  For these dummy posts, let's just modify `newAppSettings` to ignore the integrity component:

```haskell
newAppSettings :: DC AppSettings
newAppSettings = do
  lpost0 <- label (postPolicy post0 `lub` dcPublic) post0
  lpost1 <- label (postPolicy post1 `lub` dcPublic) post1
  mv <- newLMVar dcPublic $ Map.fromList 
    [(postId post0, lpost0), (postId post1, lpost1)]
  return $ AppSettings { db = mv }
```

The `lub` is used to compute the least upper bound of the two labels, ensuring that the integrity component is `True`, i.e., untrustworthy/writable by anybody, and the secrecy component is that dictated by `postPolicy`.

Now our app will get to the point of handling request.  However, if you try to create a new post or update an existing post you'll get the typical error message:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="616" height="445">

Why is this? Well, LIO stops you (the current request handler) from labeling a post with a label whose integrity component is the author unless you provide evidence that you "speak on behalf of the author" and thus have the authority to create data on the authors behalf. In LIO, code expresses authority with privileges.  In the case of this app we want to give the request handler the privilege of the currently logged-in user so that it can perform actions on behalf of the user.

Since privileges are generated by trusted code, we're going to do this in the runner code in `Main.hs` and pass our `app` a runner that executes an application that takes a privilege (in addition to the request) and produces a response. Let's modify `app` in `Application.hs` first:

```haskell
app :: (SimpleDCApplication -> DC ()) -> DC ()
app runner = do
  settings <- newAppSettings

  runner $ \currentPriv -> controllerApp settings $ do
  ...
```

Here, we're using the type alias `SimpleDCApplication` which is the same as `DCPriv -> SimpleApplication DC`, but makes it a bit easier to write when we consider middleware, for which there is corresponding type alias. In fact, let's modify our `Main.hs` function to handle apps that take privileges in addition to the request:

```haskell
...
import Data.Monoid

import LIO.Run (evalLIO, privInit)
import LIO.TCB (ioTCB)

import LIO.Web.Simple.DCLabel
import LIO.Web.Simple.TCB (runP)
...

main :: IO ()
main = do
    ...
    evalDC $ app $ runP port logStdout mempty . authMiddleware   -- Use priv
                                              . setClearanceMiddleware
                                              . setUserPrivsTCB  -- New middleware

authMiddleware :: SimpleDCMiddleware
authMiddleware app priv = basicAuth "memblog-2" (\_ _ -> return True) (app priv)

setClearanceMiddleware :: SimpleDCMiddleware
setClearanceMiddleware app priv req = do
  ...
  app priv req                               -- Now, use priv when executing app

setUserPrivsTCB :: SimpleDCMiddleware
setUserPrivsTCB app priv req = do
  case lookup "X-User" $ requestHeaders req of
    Nothing   -> app priv req                                -- No user, run with empty priv
    Just user -> do
       upriv <- ioTCB . privInit $ toCNF $ principalBS user  -- Mint priv
       app (priv `mappend` upriv) req                        -- Run app with user privs
```

Here, we had to modify all the middleware to account for the fact that apps take privileges, but the port was straight forward. There are only two things worth noting: 

1. We're now using `runP` instead of `run` and passing it the initial privilege `mempty` (effectively no privilege).

2. We added a new middleware `setUserPrivsTCB` to the pipeline which _mints_ a new privilege (with `ioTCB . privInit`) corresponding to the current user and executes the current app with this privilege.  We use `mappend` to concatenate privileges, but in this app this will always simply be the privilege corresponding to the current user, if any.  Note that this middleware uses some trusted code. As used, we can reason about its safely by simply noting that it gets executed before the `app` code (defined in `Application.hs`). For now this does not matter too much, but this is a useful design pattern -- separating out trusted and untrusted code -- and at some point we may wish to incorporate some actual untrusted code in the `app`.

Okay, so now our app takes a privilege and our runner exposes the current user's privileges to controllers in `Application.hs`, but we must also modify the database interface to take privileges if we're going to create labeled posts with the authority of the current user.

So, open up `Common.hs` and modify `insertPost`, `updatePost` and the underlying `labelPost` to additionally take a privilege:

```haskell

labelPost :: DCPriv -> Post -> DC (Labeled DCLabel Post)
labelPost priv post = labelP priv (postPolicy post) post

insertPost :: DCPriv -> Post -> DCController AppSettings PostId
insertPost priv post = do
    ...
    lpost <- labelPost priv post { postId = pId }          -- Use priv
              `onException` putLMVar (db settings) lposts
    ...

updatePost :: DCPriv -> Post -> DCController AppSettings ()
updatePost priv post = do
    ...
    lpost  <- labelPost priv post                          -- Use priv
    ...
  where guardUpdate pId lposts = do
          case Map.lookup pId lposts of
            Nothing    -> ...
            Just lpost -> guardAllocP priv (labelOf lpost) -- Use priv
```

The overall changes are straight forward: we want to make sure that we use the privilege when we label a post so `labelPost` calls `labelP` -- which is like `label` but takes a privilege -- with the supplied privilege. Similarly, when we want to assert that the current user can modify an existing labeled post we give `guardAllocP` -- which is like `guardAlloc`, but takes a privilege -- the supplied privilege. If the privilege corresponds to the author of the post the check performed by `guardAllocP` will succeed.

Lastly, we need to modify `Application.hs` to call our modified insert and update functions with the current privileges:

```haskell
    post "/" $ withUser $ \user -> do
      curPost <- formToPost user Nothing
      pId     <- insertPost currentPriv curPost
      respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
    post "/:pId" $ withUser $ \user -> do
      pId     <- queryParam' "pId"
      curPost <- formToPost user (Just pId)
      updatePost currentPriv curPost
      respond . redirectTo . S8.pack $ "/" ++ pId
```

Again, the `currentPriv` will correspond to the currently logged in user or the empty privileges if the request handler is executing on behalf of a user that's not logged in.

With these modifications, we can now update and insert new posts as usual:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

Importantly, if as user "mr-t" we try to modify "deian"'s post:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

we are going to fail:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

Of course as "deian" we can edit the post as we wish. In fact, as a final step let's modify the show controller and `liofs/views/show.html` template to show the edit link if the current user is the author of the post even for a published post.

First, modify the controller in `Application.hs` to compare the current user (if any) to the post author:

```haskell
    get "/:pId" $ do
      pId   <- queryParam' "pId"
      post  <- getPostById pId
      muser <- currentUser
      let showEdit = Just (S8.pack $ postAuthor post) == muser
      render "show.html" $ object [ "post" .= post, "showEdit" .= showEdit]
```

Here, we're using `currentUser` from `LIO.Web.Simple.Auth`, which return a `Maybe ByteString`; if the user is logged in the `muser` value is a `Just` value. Hence, we can compare against the post author (wrapped by `Just`) -- if the user is not logged in or is a different user then the "Edit post" link is not shown.

> > Note that we could also have used `withUser` from before, which would additionally force the user to log in (if they haven't), but chose the `currentUser` approach to highlight an alternative approach; in certain cases it is useful to see if the user is logged in without forcing them to do so.

Finally, let's modify the edit template accordingly:

```html
<h2>$post.postTitle$</h2>
<h3>$post.postAuthor$</h3>
<p>
  $post.postBody$
</p>
<hr />
$if(post.postIsPublished)$
  This post has been published.
$endif$
$if(showEdit)$
  <a href="/$post.postId$/edit">Edit post.</a>
$endif$
```

Now, a published post looks something like this:

<img src="data:image/png;base64," width="650" height="423">

There is lots of room to make this app actually usable (from the UI perspective) and less ugly, but for now that is all!  (Maybe just try out the other attacks I mentioned to verify that LIO prevents them!)

## Debugging

If you're extending this app it may be useful to inspect the current label and clearance at various points. You can use `getLabel` and `getClearance` to get at this information, but may need some wrapper code to either return it as part of the response or print it to the terminal. So, let's add some helper functions to do this. Let's add these functions to `Memblog/Common.hs`:

```haskell
{-# LANGUAGE OverloadedStrings #-}
...
import LIO.TCB (ioTCB)
...

-- | Get the current label and clearance as a JSON value
debugGetCtx :: DCController AppSettings Value
debugGetCtx = liftLIO $ do
  l <- getLabel
  c <- getClearance
  return $ object [ "label"     .= show l
                  , "clearance" .= show c ]

-- | Print the current label and clearance
debugPrintCtx :: DCController AppSettings ()
debugPrintCtx = liftLIO $ do
  l <- getLabel
  c <- getClearance
  ioTCB . putStrLn $ "Current label = " ++ show l
  ioTCB . putStrLn $ "Current clearance = " ++ show c
```

Above we needed some trusted code (namely, `ioTCB`) to print `stdout`.  Now, we can use `debugPrintCtx` to print the context information at any point in the controller. Similarly, we can use `debugGetCtx` to get a JSON object containing this information and pass it to a template. As an example, let's modify the index page to use this instead of `getLabel` directly. 

First, let's update the controller in `Application.hs`:

```haskell
    get "/" $ do
      posts <- getAllPosts
      ctx <- debugGetCtx
      render "index.html" $ object ["posts" .= posts, "ctx" .= ctx ]
```

Finally, let's update the `index.html` template:

```html
...
<div> Current label = $ctx.label$ </div>
<div> Current clearance = $ctx.clearance$ </div>
```

#### Log out

In addition to being able to print out the current label and clearance, we sometimes want to test the app under a different user (or no user). While we can do this by opening another browser or (Firefox with a different profile), this can get annoying pretty fast. Since we're just toying around, our app uses HTTP basic authentication. (In a real app you would change the `authMiddleware` in `Main.hs` to e.g., use [Mozilla's Persona](https://r.duckduckgo.com/l/?kh=-1&uddg=https://login.persona.org/).) And, HTTP basic authentication doesn't really have a notion of "logging out" (ah, the evolution of the web...), but we can use some of the suggestions from [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/449788/http-authentication-logout-via-php).

First, if you just want to change the current user, you can just prefix any of the app URLs with the new user's name: pointing your browser to <http://mr-t@localhost:3000/> will now change the current user to "mr-t". (This only works because we're using the `basicAuth` middleware; if we used a real authentication system the prefix is meaningless.)

But what if we want to actually log out and not run under a different user? In order to do this you have to actually remove the HTTP authentication header sent by your browser. You can do this by using the Firefox Web Developer extension (`Miscellaneous -> Clear Private Data -> HTTP Authentication`) or defining a new route in `Applicatoin.hs`:

```haskell
    get "/logout" $ do
      muser <- currentUser
      respond $ case muser of
                  Nothing -> redirectTo "/"
                  Just _  -> requestLogin
```

This route simply replies with a `401` response if you are logged in, which in your browser brings up the login dialog we saw with the `/login` route. Now if you click "Cancel" you'll get an `Authorization Required` page, which means you've logged out successfully: just point your browser to <http://localhost:3000> to see the current label and clearance.

The ugliness of this hack is immeasurable, but it's effectively what you would have to do with every other web framework while in development mode working with HTTP authentication. 

> > If you want to be a bit less disgusted take a look at the [Hails authentication middleware](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/hails-0.11.0.0/docs/Hails-HttpServer-Auth.html) ; maybe in a later post I will show you how to implement one of these with `lio-simple`.

#### Template failures (why is my page blank?)

The `simple-templates` library is work in progress, so if your template is ill formed you'll get back a blank page as opposed to a template compilation error. Unfortunately this can happen if you don't have the right number of `$`'s in your variables (or too many of them) so it's a bit subtle. The only thing you can really do right now is checkout the source in the browser and debug it `printf`-style.

> > Amit and I are working to make `simple-templates` better, but we'll also add support for other tempesting systems (e.g., [hashtash](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/hastache)) soon.

## Conclusion

This tutorial showed you how to build a secure web using _lio-simple_.  The process was not easy, but this was in part because I wanted to show you how to use LIO in a non-trivial way (and use quite a few of the features!).  In fact, you just built a somewhat simplified and app-specific version of [Hails](http://www.scs.stanford.edu/~deian/pubs/giffin:2012:hails.pdf).  Of course you can just use [hails](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/hails) if you want to build secure web apps and would rather not repeat the process, but maybe you'll want to build a variant of Hails at some point...
